org.qdt.quingo.scoping

Class QuingoScopeProvider

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.eclipse.xtext.scoping.impl.AbstractScopeProvider
      • org.eclipse.xtext.scoping.impl.DelegatingScopeProvider
        • org.qdt.quingo.scoping.AbstractQuingoScopeProvider
          • org.qdt.quingo.scoping.QuingoScopeProvider
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    org.eclipse.xtext.scoping.impl.IDelegatingScopeProvider, org.eclipse.xtext.scoping.IScopeProvider

    public class QuingoScopeProvider
extends AbstractQuingoScopeProvider
    Custom scoping for Quingo variables declared in a For statement.

    Scope is the range in which a symbol can be linked to. See https://www.eclipse.org/Xtext/documentation/303_runtime_concepts.html#scoping for details.

    Example: for (int i=0; i<5; i++) . The variable i can be used in the loop body. However, the default scoping rules of XText do not support it. Therefore, we extend the AbstractQuingoScopeProvider class to implement the desired scope rule.

    Author:
    Jintao Yu

      • getScope

        public org.eclipse.xtext.scoping.IScope getScope(org.eclipse.emf.ecore.EObject context,
                                                 org.eclipse.emf.ecore.EReference reference)
        Returns a scope for the given context.

        The scope provides access to the compatible visible EObjects for a given reference.

        Specified by:
        getScope in interface org.eclipse.xtext.scoping.IScopeProvider
        Overrides:
        getScope in class org.eclipse.xtext.scoping.impl.DelegatingScopeProvider
        Parameters:
        context - the element from which an element shall be referenced.
        reference - the reference for which to get the scope.
        Returns:
        IScope representing the innermost IScope for the passed context and reference.

      • scopeForVariable

        public org.eclipse.xtext.scoping.IScope scopeForVariable(org.eclipse.emf.ecore.EObject context,
                                                         org.eclipse.emf.ecore.EReference reference)
        The scope provider for variables.

        Specially, the function include the variable declared in the 'init' part of a For loop in the scope of variables in the loop body.

        Parameters:
        context - the element from which an element shall be referenced.
        reference - the reference for which to get the scope.
        Returns:
        IScope representing the innermost IScope for the passed context and reference.
